subject: Re: Quiki-pedia?
msgSnippet: A nice proposal, something I d like to help with. In the Shavian group they re talking about a standard spelling, isn t that an idea for us? If not, I think
messageBody:
A nice proposal, something I'd like to help with. In the Shavian
group they're talking about a standard spelling, isn't that an idea
for us?

If not, I think it's better to make one wikipedia for Quikscript and
let people make articles in different dialects in they want.

By the way; I'd use a subdomain ofwikipedia.org as it will increase
the traffic to the page (make an introduction text at the mainpage in
plain English and the rest in QS).

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Benjamin Bruce" <e-mail@...>
wrote:
>
> The idea for a "Quickipedia" is a very interesting one, but I
don't think
> we should make too much division between dialects. However, I do
think it
> important to maintain a consistant style throughout each article,
and we
> could even adopt a policy similar to Wikipedia's treatment of
British/US
>
spelling<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style#Nation
al_varieties_of_English>
> .
>
> If a separate Wikipedia were made for Quickscript, it might be a
good
> idea to license it under a Creative Commons license instead of the
GNU FDL.
> A question though, would this prevent us from transliterating
articles from
> the Roman-alphabet Wikipedia?
>
> -Benjamin Bruce
>
> 2007/6/18, amd64_hacker <amd64_hacker@...>:
> >
> > 1)Sorry, I thought we were talking about extra code points for
senior QS
> > again - an idea which I'm strongly allergic to. :)
> >
> > 2)I'm not sure I've understood you, could you explain?
> > The way I see it I don't think there is too big an issue with
having a
> > mishmash of dialects on a page.
> > An end user would still be able to read the article.
> > And it would be possible to put in redirects for the common
spellings of
> > an article's title.
> > I think it's more about having a consistent style and making
searching
> > easier.
> >
> > Of course you could have a Quikipedia for each dialect i.e.:
> > quik_us.wikipedia.org
> > quik_gb.wikipedia.org
> >
> > Or we could go with giving creating a duplicate of each article
in each
> > dialect, i.e.:
> > quik.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quikscript_(us)
> > quik.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quikscript_(gb)
> >
> > Or we could just copy the text and paste it for each dialect one
after
> > another.
> >
> > All of those options involve a lot of needless duplication of
work and
> > disk space unfortunately.
> >
> > tim_rice09 wrote:
> > >
> > > Some small questions and suggestions:
> > > 1: The abbreviations of Senior Quickscript iron out most
dialectal
> > > differences, and work pretty well with only the basic forty four
> > > letters. Why not save a load of space and use them?
> > >
> > > 2:How about instead of using one dialect (and alienate many a
> > > potential editor), have the dialects used within the articles be
> > > identified somewhere at the beginning of the page?
> > >
> > > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com <Read_Alphabet%
40yahoogroups.com>
> > > <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, amd64_hacker
> > <amd64_hacker@>
> >
> > > wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Ah, a topic I'm very interested in - transliteration. :)
> > > >
> > > > Anyone can download the database and set up their
own "wikipedia" if
> > > > they want.
> > > > So you don't actually need the permission of the wikipedia
guys to set
> > > > up Quikipedia.
> > > > Of course you won't have a dot wikipedia dot org domain name,
but it's
> > > > totally feasible.
> > > >
> > > > IMHO:
> > > >
> > > > 1) It should be typed and stored as junior quikscript.
> > > > Senior is just junior with font shaping, a rendering issue,
since
> > we're
> > > > in a wikipedia mood:
> > > > See also: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_text_layout
> > > <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_text_layout>
> > > >
> > > > 2) Easy, just use the _correct_ British pronunciation.
> > > > Just kidding (mostly) please don't flame me. :-)
> > > > You'd either have to go with one pronunciation or you'd need
to have a
> > > > separate wikipedia for each.
> > > >
> > > > 3) Which issues?
> > > > If we're talking about sorting then I'd go for:
> > > > 1-40 followed by Loch, Llan, Examine and Excite since that's
the order
> > > > they're introduced to us in The Quikscript Alphabet.
> > > >
> > > > steveb_667 wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > I have an idea & I would like some feedback on it.
> > > > >
> > > > > In short, I was wondering about the feasibility of having a
> > Wikipedia
> > > > > written entirely in Quikscript.
> > > > >
> > > > > I'm not sure if anyone has ever proposed a similar idea to
Wikipedia
> > > > > in the past. For the most part, Wikipedia has occasionally
delved
> > into
> > > > > giving artificial languages their own wiki. I have yet to
know of
> > > > > Wikipedia giving a wiki to a phonetic alphabet.
> > > > >
> > > > > It is in my view that a Quikipedia would be a great asset
to the
> > > > > existing Quikscript community. It would encourage
enrollment growth,
> > > > > increase the alphabet's visibility to a larger community of
people &
> > > > > help existing members practice with their typing skills in a
> > rewarding
> > > > > manner.
> > > > >
> > > > > Hurdles, naturally, need to be overcome for this Quikipedia
to
> > become
> > > > > reality. These concerns include, but may not be limited to,
the
> > > following:
> > > > >
> > > > > 1). What form of Quikscript to use? Junior? Senior? A mix?
> > > > >
> > > > > 2). How are we to resolve legitimate phonetic differences
with the
> > > > > same word from different countries?
> > > > >
> > > > > 3). What system should we set up to resolve emergent issues
with the
> > > > > alphabet?
> > > > >
> > > > > At any rate, have fun with the idea.
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > >
> > >
> > >
> >
> >
> >
>
> --
> Check out Ziphen Central!
> Weekly posts on interesting and unique topics.
> Newest post: "La Soledad"
> http://ziphen.benjaminbruce.com
>
